page.title: 05Macclesfield Forest Ecology
page.content:
ECOLOGY
{Geology}- The land area is formed of millstone grit which is made up of shale, sandstone and gritstone. This rock structure and the associated scenery is readily appreciated by the many visitors to the area. The upland scenery consists of sombre moorlands, which because of their poor drainage have accumulated thicknesses of peat and poor quality vegetation. The lower areas have been improved by the spreading of lime to reduce the soil acidity making the land suitable for cattle as well as sheep.
The animals graze in enclosures bounded by dry-stone walls which are a significant feature of the area. The stone was quarried locally, there now being no working quarries nearby.
